SENT.plain: Spontaneous primary medullary hemorrhage is a rare event
A 64-year-old man was admitted for sudden-onset vertigo and vomiting
His clinical features were similar to those of lateral medullary syndrome
The patient had no anticoagulant therapy, vascular malformation, or a caudal extension of a pontine hemorrhage
The patient had multiple hypertensive changes, including retinopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy on electrocardiography, multiple cerebral microbleeds, and small-vessel changes on MRI
T2(*)-weighted gradient echo MRI performed 3 months prior to admission and contrast-enhanced MRI showed no evidence of vascular malformation
We concluded that the patient had uncontrolled hypertension that may have lead to primary medullary hemorrhage
